entry.title: Re: How to Call RAP Actions with Table Types from a List Report
entry.content:
@akhileshvatupalli123464 

My example already requires frontend code. If you are asking about "opening a popup" without the need to define fragments etc., yes, it is possible with the EditFlow's invokeAction method. Instead of using ContextBinding's execute method, invokeAction integrates with the Extension API and opens a popup if parameters are required for the action.

An alternative would be to define an action that takes a single entity and returns a single result, and set the invocation grouping to "change set". This way, all the selected rows will be passed to the event handler and can be processed in one go. 

Action Definition

action actionname parameter zabs_input result [1] zabs_output;

Annotation

 @UI.lineItem: [
  {
    label: 'Activate',
    dataAction: 'myAction',
    invocationGrouping: #CHANGE_SET,
    type: #FOR_ACTION,
    position: 1 
  }
]

entry.title: Re: How to populated the VAT registration number for Business Partner correctly?
entry.content: Hello RahamanEmal, I understand your frustration with trying various combinations. Let's get more specific about populating the fields and addressing the validation check. 1. How to Populate the Fields for VAT Registration Number Correctly The key is to map the VAT registration number to the correct Tax Number Category field in your migration template. Specific Field Mapping: In the migration template for Business Partner (or Customer), you should look for fields related to "Tax Numbers." The VAT Registration Number should be mapped to the field designated for "Tax Number Category 0" (often labeled as STCEG internally). Ensure that the actual VAT number (e.g., DE123456789 for Germany) is placed in the data field corresponding to "Tax Number Category 0" for the respective Business Partner. Make sure the country code in the VAT number aligns with the country of the Business Partner. This specific mapping ensures that the system recognizes it as the official VAT registration number for that Business Partner. 2. Deactivating the "VAT Registration No. Plausibility Check" Regarding deactivating the validation rule, here's the crucial information: Standard Behavior Cannot Be Deactivated: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud (and often in on-premise for standard warnings), the warning message "Customer/Vendor is from an EU country/region; enter a VAT registration number" is part of the standard system behavior and cannot be directly deactivated through Customizing (IMG settings) or the Migration Object Modeler (LTMOM). It's a legal requirement for EU countries. (Source: userapps.support.sap.com ) Alternative: Custom Validation Rules via BADIs: While you cannot turn off the standard warning, if you need to implement different behavior (e.g., make it an informational message, or only enforce it for specific scenarios), you would typically use Business Add-Ins (BADIs). This allows you to implement custom validation logic. For instance, you could configure a BADI to: Check for the VAT number and issue a custom warning or information message that suits your business process. Potentially allow migration to proceed even with a missing VAT number under specific conditions, although this is generally not recommended for EU business partners due to legal implications. (Source: userapps.support.sap.com ) In summary, focus on correctly populating the VAT number into the Tax Number Category 0 field in your migration template. For the validation check, accept that the standard warning cannot be deactivated, and consider custom BADIs only if your specific business requirements necessitate different handling, always keeping legal compliance in mind. I hope this clarifies the steps you need to take!

entry.title: Re: How to populated the VAT registration number for Busi...
entry.content:
Hello RahamanEmal,

I understand your frustration with trying various combinations. Let's get more specific about populating the fields and addressing the validation check.
 
1. How to Populate the Fields for VAT Registration Number Correctly
The key is to map the VAT registration number to the correct Tax Number Category field in your migration template.

  • Specific Field Mapping: In the migration template for Business Partner (or Customer), you should look for fields related to "Tax Numbers." The VAT Registration Number should be mapped to the field designated for "Tax Number Category 0" (often labeled as STCEG internally).

    • Ensure that the actual VAT number (e.g., DE123456789 for Germany) is placed in the data field corresponding to "Tax Number Category 0" for the respective Business Partner.
    • Make sure the country code in the VAT number aligns with the country of the Business Partner.

    This specific mapping ensures that the system recognizes it as the official VAT registration number for that Business Partner.

2. Deactivating the "VAT Registration No. Plausibility Check"

Regarding deactivating the validation rule, here's the crucial information:

  • Standard Behavior Cannot Be Deactivated: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud (and often in on-premise for standard warnings), the warning message "Customer/Vendor is from an EU country/region; enter a VAT registration number" is part of the standard system behavior and cannot be directly deactivated through Customizing (IMG settings) or the Migration Object Modeler (LTMOM). It's a legal requirement for EU countries. (Source:

    userapps.support.sap.com

  • Alternative: Custom Validation Rules via BADIs: While you cannot turn off the standard warning, if you need to implement different behavior (e.g., make it an informational message, or only enforce it for specific scenarios), you would typically use Business Add-Ins (BADIs). This allows you to implement custom validation logic. For instance, you could configure a BADI to:

    • Check for the VAT number and issue a custom warning or information message that suits your business process.
    • Potentially allow migration to proceed even with a missing VAT number under specific conditions, although this is generally not recommended for EU business partners due to legal implications. (Source:
      userapps.support.sap.com)
 
In summary, focus on correctly populating the VAT number into the Tax Number Category 0 field in your migration template. For the validation check, accept that the standard warning cannot be deactivated, and consider custom BADIs only if your specific business requirements necessitate different handling, always keeping legal compliance in mind.

I hope this clarifies the steps you need to take!

entry.title: CAP Java Draft: Read-Only Field Not Persisted to Active Entity on Activation
entry.content:
Hi community,

I‚Äôm working with CAP Java and trying to implement soft deletion for items removed from the Object Page table.
When a user deletes an item (Composition Child) in edit mode, I mark the item as logically deleted by setting isDeleted = true.
I achieved this by setting the flag in the @On DraftService.EVENT_DRAFT_CANCEL event handler.

However, when the isDeleted field is annotated with @readonly, @Core.Immutable, or @Common.FieldControl: #ReadOnly, the flag is not transferred to the active entity when the draft is activated.
This issue occurs only in CAP Java ‚Äî the same logic works correctly in CAP Node.js.

I‚Äôve created a minimal reproducible example on GitHub:

https://github.com/miyasuta/cap-java-draft-composition-delete

Has anyone experienced similar behavior or knows whether this is a known limitation of CAP Java drafts?

entry.title: Skills Architecture Playbook: 10 Design Decisions with Talent Intelligence Hub that Define Success !
entry.content:
The shift towards a skills-based workforce is picking up speed, and this transformation lives or dies on one thing: your skills architecture, the foundation that defines:

  • how skills are structured,
  • how they are governed,
  • how they flow through your HRtech landscape, and
  • how employees, managers, and admins actually experience them.

What‚Äôs happening -
Most organizations jump straight into ‚Äúskills projects‚Äù without stopping to define the design decisions that truly matter! I have seen SAP SuccessFactors customers engaging with different HRTech or Skills vendors separately, rather than as a coherent group. The result? Duplicate skills across systems, messy job profiles, confused employees, frustrated managers, and governance models held together with duct tape.

Think of this blog as your Skills Architecture Playbook: the 10 decisions every company must get right to build a clean, future-proof foundation with Talent Intelligence Hub. These decisions will shape everything from AI models and inference reliability to employee growth journeys and manager adoption.

If you‚Äôre implementing TIH, planning a Skills Transformation, or just trying to bring order to the skills chaos, this guide is for you.

Let‚Äôs get into the decisions that define your success.

Leading Practice Skills Architecture with Talent Intelligence Hub

Here‚Äôs a leading practice approach for designing a Skills Architecture with TIH at its core. Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners help augment and complement customers' internal data, creating a high-quality skills foundation that brings together market skills data, job and work insights, and people attributes.

Once standardized in Talent Intelligence Hub and enriched with employee and organizational master data from SuccessFactors, this unified skills intelligence can be delivered through Career and Talent Development (CTD) as the experience layer for every persona -employees, managers, HR, recruiters, and leaders.

I had shared this diagram in my session at SuccessConnect and have further explained it in my podcast. Give it a listen -  Art of the Possible - Episode 1 - Skills-based Transformation - Talent Alchemy Podcast series

This is how you bring a skills-based transformation concept to life.

1. Choose Your System of Record: Where Does Job & Skills Truth Live?

Everything starts with a single question: Where does the truth sit? 

For job architecture and skills governance, SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub should be your system of record and governance layer.

Here‚Äôs how it breaks down:

TIH + JPB = Your Master Foundation

  • Job Families
  • Job Roles
  • Job Profiles
  • Skills Library
  • Skills tagged to roles and profiles
  1. JPB holds your job architecture. 
  2. Open Skills Ecosystem partners enrich your skills library.
  3. TIH governs and standardizes everything.

Get this foundation right, and the rest of your skills strategy becomes infinitely easier.

2. Standardize Skills in the Attributes Library with AI Skills Standardization

Once you know where the truth lives, the next step is: What does that truth look like? The Attributes Library in TIH is your governance layer for all skills master data.

It helps you:

  • Maintain a clean, unified skills library.
  • Standardizes the Skills data into one common language. 
  • Manage lifecycle states (active, deprecated, standardized)
  • Standardize proficiency scales

Your Open Skills Ecosystem partner sends business- and industry-relevant skill data into TIH, where you standardize it.

This avoids:

  • Duplicate skills
  • Confusing naming conventions
  • Skill inflation
  • Random ‚ÄúHR-created‚Äù one-off skills

This is your quality control engine.

Check out my Talent Alchemy Bits and Bytes segment, where I talked about Skills Standardization. 

3. Decide How Skills Will Be Validated

If there‚Äôs one thing employees love, it‚Äôs adding skills. If there‚Äôs one thing managers love‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs being skeptical of those skills. Validation matters!

You need to decide: 

Who validates the skills?

  • Employee?
  • Manager?
  • Both?
  • Or does it depend on the skill type?

What‚Äôs the sequence?

  • Employee declares ‚Üí Manager approves
  • Manager nominates ‚Üí Employee confirms
  • System infers ‚Üí Employee validates ‚Üí Manager approves

Consistency is key.

Which system is the system of record for validation?

TIH/Growth Portfolio or your OSE partner?

Either works‚Äîjust don‚Äôt let both do it independently. That‚Äôs how data chaos is born.

4. Define Your Skills Signals Strategy

Skills come from everywhere. Projects, learning, bots, assessments‚Ä¶ even legacy tools that are somehow still alive. Your rule of survival:  SAP SuccessFactors Growth Portfolio should be the master system of record for all employee skill interactions.

That means:

  • Employees view and update skills here
  • Managers make decisions here
  • HR governs here
  • Partners feed into here

Other systems can contribute, but they can‚Äôt own the truth

5. Choose What Skills You will Infer and from Where?

Skill inferencing is magical‚Ä¶ unless it pulls the wrong signals. You need to define:

What external sources can infer skills?

  • Project systems
  • Legacy HR/LMS tools
  • External learning platforms
  • Gig/mobility platforms
  • Assessment vendors

How will you judge quality?

Set thresholds such as:

  • Evidence required
  • Confidence level
  • Relevance to job or industry
  • Duplication rules

Which SF processes continuously infer skills?

  • Learning completions
  • Internal gigs
  • Performance achievements
  • Career development activities

A thoughtful inferencing strategy prevents ‚Äúnoise skills‚Äù and keeps your profiles trustworthy.

6. Decide Where Employee Skills Data Should Flow

Once an employee‚Äôs skills are updated and validated, where does that data go?

Typical downstream consumers include:

  • Recruiting
  • Learning
  • Opportunity Marketplace
  • Workforce planning
  • Career & succession tools
  • Assessment vendors
Important: "If you have multiple skills-enabled vendors (LMS, recruiting, assessment tools), Growth Portfolio remains the master. Application partners consume standardized data; they don‚Äôt manage it. This keeps your ecosystem clean and consistent."

7. Define How the Skills Taxonomy Will Be Propagated

Your skills taxonomy flows outward from TIH into the rest of the ecosystem.

TIH is your:

  • Skills system of record
  • Job architecture governance tool
  • Standardization engine
  • Master metadata source

If you use multiple Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners:

Pick ONE to be your skills architecture provider. Why?

Because multiple skills dictionaries = chaos.
One dictionary + TIH governance = sanity.

8. Design the Employee Experience (Growth Portfolio and..)

Employees are the heart of your skills ecosystem. Decide:

How much ownership do they have?

  • Full self-declaration
  • Only inferred skills
  • Only validated skills
  • Only view or able to manage skills
  • A blended model

What should they see?

  • Validated skills
  • Inferred skills
  • Critical or core skills
  • Skill gaps

How guided should their experience be?

  • Single entry inside SuccessFactors
  • Some interactions inside partner tools
  • Or a completely unified Growth Portfolio experience

The goal?
Keep it simple, intuitive, and aligned to growth, not admin work.

9. Design the Manager Experience (Teams View and...)

Managers are where skills turn into results, development, mobility, and readiness. You need to define:

How much oversight managers have: Do they validate? Approve? Only for critical skills?

How deeply do skills feed talent decisions

Should they use skills to:

  • Recommend learning
  • Suggest gigs
  • Nominate for roles
  • Support succession plans
  • Plan team capabilities

What feedback loops they own

After:

  • Projects
  • Assignments
  • Reskilling initiatives

Manager feedback becomes key evidence for skill proficiency.

10. Design the Admin Experience (Governance, Analytics, and ...)

Admins run the heartbeat of your skills ecosystem. Define:

Who owns the skills library?

  • HR COE?
  • Talent?
  • Learning?
  • A cross-functional governance team?

How partners integrate

External vendors must feed into Growth Portfolio without duplicating or reinventing your skills.

What KPIs HR will track

Some examples:

  • % validated critical skills
  • Internal fill rate
  • Mobility rate
  • Skills coverage vs. demand
  • Time-to-proficiency
  • Learning-to-skills conversion

Conclusion: Your Skills Architecture Is Your Future

Building a skills-based organization is not about collecting skills, it‚Äôs about creating a system of truth, a system of intelligence, and most importantly, a system of experience that employees and managers trust.

  • Talent Intelligence Hub gives you the governance layer.
  • Growth Portfolio with CTD (Career & Talent Development solution) provides the experience layer.
  • Your open ecosystem partners give you the enrichment layer.

But your design decisions tie it all together.

Get these decisions right, and skills become the engine behind: talent mobility, workforce agility, learning personalization, internal career growth, and more. Get them wrong, and you‚Äôll spend months reconciling data, chasing inconsistencies, and wondering why adoption is low.

With Talent Intelligence Hub at the center and these 10 decisions guiding your journey, you can build not only an architecture, but a future-ready, human-centered skills ecosystem that actually works.

entry.title: Re: BSX Account Transaction After applying SAP Note 1677806
entry.content:
Hi @Gomez 
The issue you‚Äôre seeing (BSX posting alongside TXO after applying SAP Note 1677806) is a known side effect when the posting string WA04 is not fully aligned with the BAdI implementation. The note specifies that only TXO should be triggered, but if BSX is still appearing, it usually means the posting string or account determination logic is incomplete or misapplied in your S/4HANA 2023 environment. To resolve this you have to do following as mentioned below.

1. Check Posting String WA04
Ensure WA04 is correctly assigned in the BAdI implementation as per the SAP Note. WA04 should explicitly exclude BSX and only trigger TXO.

2. Validate OBYC Settings
In transaction OBYC, review the BSX and TXO account determination. Confirm that BSX is not linked to movement type 541 after the note implementation.

3. Debug the BAdI Execution
Run a test posting with movement 541 and debug the BAdI logic. Verify whether WA04 is being called and whether BSX is being added by fallback logic.

4. Raise an OSS Incident
Since you‚Äôre on S/4HANA Private 2023, this may be a regression or adaptation gap. SAP Support can provide a correction transport or updated note for your release.

Hope this will help you

entry.title: Re: S4H: Print Freight Condition Total Value after Revisi...
entry.content:
Hello @TaniaTrindade 

what i understand purchasing/print form issue where the freight condition (header-level condition) is being recalculated or displayed incorrectly after partial GR and PO revision. My suggestion for you to do the following as mentioned below.

1. Print from Header Condition Directly
Adjust the PO print form (SmartForm / Adobe Form) logic to read the freight condition value from the header (EKPO/EKKO + KONV) instead of summing item-level distributed values. This way, the printout always shows the full freight cost (500 USD), regardless of GR status.

2. Use Condition Value (KONV)
In KONV, freight condition (e.g., FRB1, HD00, or custom Z-condition) is stored with header indicator. Fetch the KWERT (condition value) for the freight condition at header level. Ensure the print program doesn‚Äôt filter by open items only.

3. Custom Logic in Print Program
Enhance the PO output program (usually MEDRUCK or custom ZMEDRUCK) to, check if the condition is header-level. Print the total value (500 USD) instead of the distributed item values. This avoids dependency on GR status.

4. Alternative: Display Both
Some clients prefer showing, Total freight (header) = 500 USD then Remaining freight (open items) = 100 USD. This can be achieved by printing both header condition and distributed item condition values.

Identify the freight condition type in your system (check PO conditions tab). In the print form logic, if condition is header-level ‚Üí print KONV-KWERT directly.
If condition is item-level ‚Üí sum across items.
Test with revised PO where GR is partial to confirm.

Let me know if you need more clarity.

entry.title: Re: Can you remember the first time you heard of SAP
entry.content:
I was working as a production engineer in a manufacturing company, handling the production schedule, machine maintenance, and the assembly line workforce. When the management decided to implement SAP, I wasn‚Äôt familiar with it at all.

Consultants began visiting our factory to work with the core team and I was also involved in the discussions. I got a chance to speak to one of the consultants during a lunch break, and that conversation introduced me to SAP and its career possibilities. I realized that I could also be a part of this field.

Although I was interested, I was hesitant to take the leap because I didn‚Äôt come from a software background. I discussed it with one of my colleagues, who was initially unsure as well, but eventually we both decided to enroll and pursue a career in SAP.

entry.title: Re: ASM mode not calling custom request mapping for CCV2...
entry.content: The reason why the overridden request was not invoked was due to the request mapping not be the same. The OOTB endpoint used a request used a mapping of @GetMapping and the override used the older @RequestMapping. Once they were aligned the overridden request endpoint was invoked.

entry.title: CKMLCP reversal
entry.content:
Hello specialists,
I was running CKMLCP, and when I executed the Closing Entry step, it returned the period lock error +716. I reversed the Closing Entry and Costing steps, but I am unable to reverse the Preparation and Selection steps. In the Lock column, there are red circles with an X, which means that the period was not locked for execution. How can I reverse the Preparation steps so that I can lock the period and run the process again?

entry.title: Re: HU number is not distributed/EWM removing the HU number
entry.content:
Hi,

Have you checked the outbound queue (SMQ1) of your ERP system? Does the queue container have the HU data you are expecting?

Alternatively on the EWM side: have you checked the inbound queue (SMQ2)?

You can deregister the queues with SMQE or SMQR respectively to stop processing and then re-test to produce a new queue entry.

Regards Andreas

entry.title: @cap-js/mcp-server - Practical guide to get value on day on
entry.content:
Give your coding assistant instant, project‚Äëaware knowledge of your CAP model and docs. With @cap-js/mcp-server, the assistant can look up entities, services, fields, and HTTP endpoints from your compiled CDS model and cross‚Äëcheck official CAP docs, so it proposes the right code and changes in your editor.

Here's where I found this and would like to share with community - https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

  • Package: @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Command: cds-mcp
  • Tools: search_model (compiled CDS/CSN), search_docs (local CAP docs embeddings)
  • Works with MCP‚Äëcapable assistants in VS Code and other IDEs (e.g., Cline, Copilot Agent Mode, opencode)

Here‚Äôs the short version - just follow these 3 step

  1. Configure your IDE agent to start the server via npx:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}
  1. Add these rules to AGENTS.md so the assistant always uses the server correctly:
- You MUST search for CDS definitions, like entities, fields and services (which include HTTP endpoints) with cds-mcp, only if it fails you MAY read *.cds files in the project.
- You MUST search for CAP docs with cds-mcp EVERY TIME you create, modify CDS models or when using APIs or the `cds` CLI from CAP. Do NOT propose, suggest or make any changes without first checking it.
  1. Optional CLI smoke test:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Why you‚Äôll love it

  • Stop guessing: Fuzzy‚Äësearch your compiled model for entities, services, elements, annotations, and endpoints.
  • Fewer mistakes: Suggestions are grounded in your actual model and verified against official CAP docs.
  • All local: Fast and private, perfect for day‚Äëto‚Äëday development.

IDE setup

VS Code - Cline extension

Settings example:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}

VS Code - GitHub Copilot Agent Mode (global mcp.json)

{
  "servers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {},
      "type": "stdio"
    },
    "inputs": []
  }
}

opencode

{
  "mcp": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "type": "local",
      "command": ["npx", "-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}

Tip: Keep the server name ‚Äúcds-mcp‚Äù in both your config and prompts so your assistant reliably calls it.

How to use it in your editor

Think ‚Äúdiscover first, then change.‚Äù Ask your assistant to:

  • Discover model and endpoints

    • ‚ÄúUse cds‚Äëmcp search_model to list all services and their HTTP endpoints. Then list entities with primary keys.‚Äù

  • Write a correct SELECT with expand

    • ‚ÄúCall cds‚Äëmcp search_model for Books and its associations. Then, after checking CAP Node.js SELECT expand syntax via cds‚Äëmcp search_docs, propose a handler that returns Books.title, Books.stock and expands auther.name.‚Äù

  • Generate precise OData URLs

    • ‚ÄúFind the service and endpoint for Books via search_model, then give me an OData V4 URL with $select=title,stock and $expand=author($select=name) plus a curl example.‚Äù

  • Safely change CDS/annotations

    • ‚ÄúShow docs for @Common.Label using cds‚Äëmcp search_docs. Using search_model for Books, propose a minimal diff adding labels for title and stock. Include file paths.‚Äù

  • Plan a refactor

    • ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre renaming Author to Writer. With cds‚Äëmcp search_model, list affected entities, associations, services, and endpoints; propose a step‚Äëby‚Äëstep PR plan.‚Äù

  • Implement an action/handler

    • ‚ÄúFind docs on defining and implementing a custom action in Node.js via cds‚Äëmcp search_docs. Then sketch a minimal handler in srv/<service>.js with imports and input validation.‚Äù

Best practice: Ask the assistant to paste the search_model and search_docs results that justify any change.

CLI usage (optional but handy)

Install globally to test from your terminal:

npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Search your compiled model:
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
  • Search CAP documentation:
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Once the CLI works, your IDE agent can invoke the same tools automatically.

What the tools return

  • search_model

    • Names and kinds (entity, service, etc.)
    • Elements and annotations
    • File locations
    • HTTP endpoints where services are exposed

  • search_docs

    • The most relevant CAP documentation snippets for your query, based on local embeddings

Use both together: discover exact names/paths with search_model, confirm syntax and best practices with search_docs, then apply small, reviewable changes.

Tips for getting the most value

  • Start every task with search_model to avoid typos and stale assumptions.
  • Require docs‚Äëbacked edits: have the assistant run search_docs before proposing code.
  • Keep edits atomic: one focused change at a time, with file paths and minimal diffs.
  • Monorepo? Tell the assistant the CAP project folder to search.

Support and contribution

  • Issues and feature requests: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/issues
  • Security policy: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/security/policy
  • Code of Conduct: https://github.com/cap-js/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
  • License and REUSE info: see LICENSE and https://api.reuse.software/info/github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

Now action - 

  • Add the MCP config, paste the two rules into AGENTS.md, and ask your assistant:
    ‚ÄúDiscover all entities, keys, and endpoints with cds‚Äëmcp search_model, verify the Node.js SELECT docs with cds‚Äëmcp search_docs, then propose a minimal handler change for Books.‚Äù

    SAP Business Technology Platform  SAP Business AI SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: Re: Serial Number Profile : Prefix (CBC activity 103636)
entry.content:
Hello @adrien_delanoe

The serialisation procedure you see in the WM view has nothing to do with the serial number prefix from SSCUI 103636, the serial number profile used in your inventory management, or equipment master serial number ranges. These are two different frameworks.

To answer your question, the serialisation procedure is used to defined whether EWM should enforce serialisation, at which step your system captures the serial numbers, whether thy are managed at storage bin level/stock level or for duplicate validation. This basically means that this field only controls your operational behaviour but not the number ranges.

However, the serial number profile SSCUI 103636 is the only part that affects the number created. Which also addresses what I clarified in my earlier answer. Meaning it only applies when you use EWM serialisation and not Inventory Management.

My initial guidance steps were focused on showing that the prefix only works inside EWM serialisation, the need to activate it for your material to be extended and to inform you that without it, your system will not use the warehouse serialisation setting, leading to prefix not appearing.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: RF Device printing issue -SAP WM Public Cloud 2508
entry.content:
Good day @SaleemSk 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

HU Shipping Label, Sources of Condition Parameters Used in Output Parameter Determination, Integration of Handling Units, SCM-EWM-PRN - Printing, Overview of Handling Units.

In summary, the current public cloud release does not enable the F1 Pack function to trigger HU label output. That is the reason why your system does not create the print queue when you press F1 pack, even though HU label printing works from the packing work center and the warehouse monitor.

In public cloud, HU label printing in these apps is not driven by the output parameter determination app. The system does not expose HU label output types there and there is no configuration or BAdI that allows you to automatically call HU label printing.

Due to public cloud‚Äôs clean-core restrictions, you may either print HU labels from the packing work center or warehouse monitor after your packing or you use RF printing transaction and trigger printing through the RF print function key and not through the F1 Pack.

Also considering the public cloud's clean-core principle restricts RF transaction modification, should you require automatic printing directly from F1 pack, you can only achieve that through an external or BTP-based extension.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
entry.content:
In a world where governments are rapidly digitizing tax controls, companies must ensure real-time reporting, accurate e-invoicing, and seamless integration with local authorities. SAP has long supported these needs through its Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solution embedded in SAP S/4HANA.

As regulatory demands increase and cloud adoption accelerates, SAP introduced Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition‚Äîa next-generation, cloud-native platform designed to help enterprises respond faster, comply globally, and scale efficiently.

This article explains both solutions and highlights the key differences that set the Cloud Edition apart.

 

What Is SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)?

DRC is the integrated compliance framework within SAP S/4HANA, built to support:

  • Electronic invoicing (eDocuments)

  • Legal reporting (SAF-T, VAT, Intrastat, etc.)

  • Indirect tax submissions

  • Real-time government integrations

  • Audit and compliance workflows

DRC leverages SAP S/4HANA‚Äôs core capabilities, using:

  • Embedded data models

  • Fiori apps

  • Integration with finance and logistics

  • Local add-ons for country-specific mandates

It is ideal for companies that run S/4HANA (on-premise, private cloud or public cloud) and want compliance deeply integrated into transactional flows.

What Is Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition?

DRC Cloud Edition is SAP‚Äôs standalone, cloud-native compliance platform built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

It is designed to:

  • Support global e-invoicing mandates

  • Manage content-rich regulatory reporting

  • Centralize compliance across multiple ERP systems

  • Provide API-based connections to government platforms

  • Deliver continuous updates through the cloud

Unlike DRC embedded in S/4HANA, the Cloud Edition does not depend on the ERP release cycle, allowing SAP to push compliance updates faster and support new regulations more rapidly.

Key Differentiators: DRC vs. DRC Cloud Edition

Below are the main areas where the Cloud Edition differentiates itself from the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA.

1. Deployment Architecture

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
LocationRuns inside SAP S/4HANARuns outside ERP, on SAP BTP
DependenciesTied to ERP version & upgradesIndependent of ERP release cycle
UpdatesDelivered with S/4HANA feature packsContinuous cloud updates

Benefit: Faster adoption of new regulatory requirements with minimal impact on the ERP.

2. Multi-ERP and Non-SAP Integration

Aspect DRC DRC Cloud Edition
Supported systemsPrimarily SAP S/4HANAMulti-ERP, multi-system, including non-SAP
ConsolidationUsually per ERP instanceCentralized compliance hub

Benefit: Ideal for companies with multiple ERPs, global rollouts, or hybrid landscapes.

3. Scalability and Global Coverage

  • DRC Cloud Edition can scale more easily across countries.

  • SAP delivers regulatory content globally through cloud content packages.

  • Government API connectivity is managed centrally.

Benefit: Enterprises expand into new jurisdictions without large ERP projects.

4. Government Integrations and Connectivity

DRC Cloud Edition offers:

  • Managed API gateways to tax authorities

  • Continuous monitoring of government system changes

  • Central message tracking across countries

Benefit: Reduces IT workload and ensures higher resilience for e-invoicing and e-reporting.

5. Innovation, AI and Extensibility

Because it sits on SAP BTP, DRC Cloud Edition can leverage:

  • AI-driven anomaly detection

  • Intelligent validation of documents

  • Faster extensibility via low-code tools

  • Cloud automation services

Benefit: More innovation potential compared to the ERP-embedded DRC.

6. Upgrade Effort and Maintenance

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
Customer effortMust test with ERP upgradesMinimal customer testing
UpdatesPeriodicContinuous and automatic
MaintenanceShared between ERP team and tax complianceFully handled in the cloud

Benefit: Lower TCO and faster compliance readiness.

When to Choose Each Solution?

Choose DRC (Embedded in S/4HANA) if:

  • You want compliance tightly integrated into transactional finance and logistics.

  • You prefer a single solution inside S/4HANA.

  • You operate primarily in countries already supported within DRC.

Choose DRC Cloud Edition if:

  • You need global multi-country e-invoicing with fast deployment.

  • You operate multiple ERPs or hybrid landscapes.

  • You want rapid response to changing government mandates.

  • You need a future-proof cloud strategy with continuous innovation.

Conclusion

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition represents the evolution of digital tax compliance‚Äîfaster, more scalable, and designed for a global, multi-system world.

While the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA remains a strong and deeply integrated option, the Cloud Edition expands capabilities with:

  • Cloud-native architecture

  • Faster regulatory updates

  • Centralized global management

  • Support for multiple ERPs

  • Continuous innovation via SAP BTP

Together, both solutions equip organizations to meet today‚Äôs regulatory environment and future-proof their compliance landscape.

entry.title: ¬øQu√© es IFRS 18? Explicaci√≥n e Impacto para Clientes de SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
IFRS 18 redefine c√≥mo se presentan resultados; en SAP S/4HANA implica reestructurar reportes, cuentas y subtotales para lograr transparencia, comparabilidad y cumplimiento global.

1. ¬øQu√© es IFRS 18?

IFRS 18 ‚Äì Presentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements es la nueva norma emitida por IASB que sustituye a IAS 1.
Su objetivo es estandarizar y hacer m√°s comparables los estados financieros entre empresas, mejorando la transparencia y consistencia en:

  • Presentaci√≥n del estado de resultados

  • Clasificaci√≥n de gastos

  • Subtotales obligatorios

  • Informaci√≥n por ‚Äúgesti√≥n‚Äù (management approach)

  • Notas y revelaciones

Entrar√° en vigor a partir de 2027 (con adopci√≥n anticipada permitida).

2. ¬øQu√© cambia con IFRS 18? Principales novedades

A) Nuevas categor√≠as obligatorias en el Estado de Resultados

IFRS 18 introduce tres nuevas categor√≠as estandarizadas:

  1. Operating (Operativas)

  2. Investing (Inversiones)

  3. Financing (Financiamiento)

‚Äî adem√°s de requerir subtotales como Operating Profit.

B) Mayor claridad en gastos por funci√≥n o por naturaleza

Las empresas deben elegir un solo enfoque principal y justificarlo.
Requiere revelaciones adicionales cuando los gastos se presentan por funci√≥n.

C) Subtotales estandarizados obligatorios

Incluye m√©tricas que antes eran voluntarias, ahora definidas bajo una gu√≠a uniforme.

D) Reglas m√°s estrictas para ‚ÄúManagement-defined Performance Measures (MPM)‚Äù

Cualquier KPI financiero que la administraci√≥n use (como EBITDA ajustado, margen recurrente, etc.) debe:

  • Definirse formalmente

  • Explicarse

  • Conciliarse con IFRS

  • Divulgarse consistentemente

E) Cambios en notas y estructura narrativa

Nuevos requerimientos de presentaci√≥n de informaci√≥n complementaria, con foco en consistencia.

3. Impacto para los clientes que utilizan SAP S/4HANA

1. Ajustes en el modelo de reporting financiero

Se deber√°n adaptar:

  • Estructuras del P&L

  • Versiones de reporte

  • Hierarqu√≠as financieras

  • Indicadores y subtotales

La nueva estructuraci√≥n se resuelve especialmente con SAP Group Reporting.

2. Cambios en el modelo de cuentas y asignaciones

IFRS 18 exigir√° revisar:

  • Clasificaci√≥n de gastos operativos vs. no operativos

  • Determinaci√≥n de categor√≠as (operativa, inversi√≥n, financiamiento)

  • Cuentas contables y agrupaciones en FS Items

Esto puede requerir ajustes en:

  • Chart of Accounts (COA)

  • FS Item derivation

  • Profit center / Segment assignments

3. Reconfiguraci√≥n de reportes y KPIs

IFRS 18 exige nuevos subtotales estandarizados como:

  • Operating Profit

  • Profit before Financing and Investing

  • Profit before Income Taxes

En SAP se habilitan mediante:

  • Fiori Analytical Apps

  • SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Group Reporting Data Collection (GRDC)

4. Impacto en empresas que usan CO-PA / Margin Analysis

Se necesitar√°n:

  • Nuevas derivaciones para categor√≠as operativas/financieras

  • Alineaci√≥n entre rentabilidad operativa interna y estado de resultados IFRS

Margin Analysis facilitar√° este alineamiento gracias al Universal Journal.

5. Mayor importancia de SAP Group Reporting

Group Reporting ser√° cr√≠tico porque:

  • Permite mapear FS Items a categor√≠as IFRS 18

  • Ajustar subtotales en consolidaci√≥n

  • Alinear reportes individuales y consolidados

  • Gestionar KPI definidos por la administraci√≥n (MPMs)

6. Impacto en divulgaci√≥n y notas financieras

Con IFRS 18, empresas deber√°n generar notas m√°s estructuradas y reconciliaciones nuevas.
SAP facilitar√° esto a trav√©s de:

  • GRDC (Group Reporting Data Collection)

  • Disclosure Management Tools

  • Plantillas estandarizadas para notas

7. Cambios en SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)

Para empresas que generen reportes locales a partir de estados IFRS, los cambios en P&L obligan a:

  • Revisar layouts

  • Ajustar reportes regulatorios

  • Sincronizar derivaciones financieras

4. ¬øQu√© deben hacer los clientes de SAP S/4HANA?

Acciones recomendadas:

1. Evaluaci√≥n del modelo actual de P&L

Comparar la estructura existente vs. la requerida por IFRS 18.

2. Impact assessment t√©cnico y funcional

Revisar COA, derivaciones, Fiori reports y Group Reporting.

3. Adecuaci√≥n del reporting consolidado

Mapeo de FS Items ‚Üí Nuevas categor√≠as IFRS 18.

4. Ajustes en KPIs internos y MPMs

Alinear definiciones con la norma.

5. Actualizaci√≥n de procesos financieros

Cerrar brechas en notas, conciliaciones y subtotales.

entry.title: Re: the CDS of APP Monitor Value Chains
entry.content:
Hi @omega-ou 

Thank you for your question.

In public cloud you cannot use the monitor value chain app to build your report due to the lack of a CDS view that does that. The reason is SAP does not expose value chain engine tables or CDS views in public cloud. The app is based on internal reuse components that are not released for reporting, not visible in View Browser and not extendable through custom CDS.

To build your report, you must join the released analytical cubes yourself.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Mass migration of master data and fixed asset postings
entry.content:
Hello @SFerrand 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not provide any API or BAdI to migrate fixed asset master data or values. The best option is to stick to the migration cockpit and split the load into smaller batches.

I suggest you break the assets into batches of 20-50k assets per run. Then split your postings into multiple files.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @DianaRoesner 

Honestly, I came away very disappointed with the certification process. It makes me wonder if SAP has ever properly tested the UI.

I had read about the problems others faced ‚Äî especially with submitting answers ‚Äî and I tried the BDC certificate hoping those issues wouldn‚Äôt happen again. But the trouble started right away.

After accepting the agreement, I had to set up my camera and microphone. I did that, but the ‚ÄúStart‚Äù button stayed disabled, saying the camera wasn‚Äôt set. Refreshing didn‚Äôt help. Strangely, I could still click ‚ÄúStart,‚Äù but then I got a shocking error message.

I tried clicking ‚ÄúRestart,‚Äù just like it said, but that didn‚Äôt fix anything. The same error message popped up again.

I tried ‚ÄúContact Us,‚Äù but instead of SAP support, I landed on a page from yoodli.ai. It just said ‚ÄúHow can we help you?‚Äù ‚Äî with no input box at all.  ????!!!!

On their website, the chat told me: ‚ÄúSend us a message, we‚Äôll be back online tomorrow.‚Äù   !!!!!!!!

What made it worse was that the exam timer kept ticking down from two hours, even though I couldn‚Äôt access the exam at all. It was incredibly frustrating ‚Äî just sitting there watching the clock run out on something I couldn‚Äôt even start. And then, after two hours, the system simply said ‚ÄúTime‚Äôs up,‚Äù and counted the attempt as failed.

So my questions are:

  • Was this UI ever properly tested before being rolled out?
  • Why hand over such an important exam process to a third-party company?
  • Shouldn‚Äôt certification exams be held on working days, when support is available, instead of weekends? Because if not, then the whole idea of ‚Äòanywhere, anytime‚Äô doesn‚Äôt make sense anymore.
  • And most importantly: how do I get back my attempt count for a test that never even began?

I‚Äôve already opened a support case with the Learning Support Team, and I really hope they answer quickly ‚Äî even on the weekend ‚Äî

entry.title: Re: Clicking ‚ÄúComponents Missing‚Äù in Manage Production Or...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

  1. Answer to question 1: This often happens if target app could not be found and it therefore returns you to the homepage. Potentially the app is not assigned to your business role.
  2. Answer to question 2: Yes, they are.
  3. Answer to question 3: You need either one of the following roles: SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR which ensures you have the planner rights in production or SAP_BR_PRODN_SUPERVISOR which gives you the supervisor permission.
  4. Answer to question 4: Yes, it is common in the demo tenants. This is because, in the demo tenants the full catalog are not deployed. Some objects are missing; the missing Parts app and some cross-navigation mappings are either missing or incomplete. As a result, when you click the link, you are routed back to the Launchpad.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Monitor External Requirements ‚Äì ‚ÄúToo many data record...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

To answer your first question, yes it is if your filter function does not cover the required fields.

The system seems to be working as designed. If you miss any critical selection parameter, the backend reads the full MRP dataset and triggers too many records and thereby returns no results. Which then shows no data.

First, I suggest you also filter the Requirement Evaluation Period to limit the search the system carries out. If something is available, the system should generate data.

Alternatively, it could also mean you have no external requirement open for the chosen plants and products. and therefore, no data is generated. I ran the test and the system also provided no data.

What I also did is to run a check on the Monitor Material Coverage APP. As you can see below, the system produced some data showing there are shortages. I suggest you check in this app using the same materials on your screenshot to evaluate if you have some shortages. If you did not find any, then the Alert.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Hide company code by default
entry.content:
Good day @TobiasVoigt 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Configuring Business Roles, Assigning Business Roles to a User, Best Practices for Business Roles, How to Create a Business Role from a Template, Restricting Access Roles, Manage Consolidation Hierarchies

To summarise, the public cloud provides the restriction request through business role restrictions and not through structural configuration. The simplest clean-core way to do what you are intending, is to create one dedicated role that explicitly allows this company code, while all other roles remain without access. Which then means, only users with this special role will see the company code in apps, analytics and value helps. This helps you avoid role duplication.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Copy Text from Sevrice Order to Billing Document
entry.content:
Good day @simon_all4cloud41 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not offer the possibility to transfer service order or service confirmation texts directly into the Billing Document text tabs. You can only do that for SD documents.

Considering the public cloud principle restricts some functionalities, you can only achieve your requirements without custom fields by including the text in the billing output PDF and enabling a service confirmation text through output parameter determination and then map it into the billing form.

However, if your business requirement is to store the text inside the Billing Document itself, you can achieve it only through custom field and custom logic.

Have a look at the following references.

Service Processing Using a Service Order, Service Order Processing,  Service Order - Confirm Processing, Billing Document, Output Determination in the Billing Document

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Event Driven SAP CAP on Kyma with Agentic AI and UI Auto Refresh
entry.content:
Introduction:
This prototype demonstrates how a simple CAP application can evolve into an event-driven architecture enriched with autonomous agentic AI. The objective was to show how CAP can react to external events in real time, refresh the UI automatically, and trigger an AI workflow that identifies duplicate citizens without any user action. The solution combines Kyma, SAP CAP, SAP HANA Cloud DB, SAP Integration Suite, a Python agent/Open AI, all running together.

Demo:

End-to-End Flow:
This application is built around a simple idea: when a citizen is created in the system, everything should react automatically.

The process starts in SAP Integration Suite. This is the continuation of the last Blog Post . The iFlow inserts the new citizen into HANA Cloud and then calls CAP‚Äôs notify endpoint with a simple JSON payload. This notify call is the explicit trigger, because CAP does not detect database changes on its own. Once CAP receives the notification, it broadcasts the event through its citizen stream endpoint using Server-Sent Events.

The UI and the Python agent are both listening to this stream. When they receive the event, each reacts independently. The UI refreshes its Fiori Elements binding and displays the new record. The agent retrieves the citizen through CAP OData, performs duplicate detection, prompts Open AI, and writes its suggestions back through CAP. CAP exposes the suggestions via virtual enrichment fields so that the UI automatically displays AI insights during the next read.

 

iFlow Changes:

Code:

GitHub: User - shahidla. Repository - citizen-master-cap-docker

Agentic AI:
The agent is packaged as a Python container running in Kyma. It listens continuously to the citizen stream. When it receives a CitizenCreated event it reads the citizen through OData, prompts Open AI with a structured tool-based instruction set and follows the returned JSON. Open AI selects the next actions such as fetching the citizen again, running a duplicate search or writing the final suggestion.

To make the AI transparent, a thinking log table records each step in the agent run including search inputs, candidate lists, scores and final reasoning. Users can view not only the AI result but also how the agent reached that conclusion. This makes the system trustworthy and audit friendly rather than a black box.

Execution results:

AI Agent Thinking Logs:

Conclusion:
This prototype shows that a CAP application can be extended into a fully event driven and agentic AI and can all run together inside Kyma without additional infrastructure The result is a responsive and intelligent application that reacts to new information immediately and explains every decision it makes.

Disclaimer:
This prototype intended for learning and demonstration. It is not production grade and does not include full durability. AI reasoning results should be validated and not used for decisions without proper governance. A real solution would require reviewing security, performance, and data privacy aspects. Terminology may have been used freely as part of experimentation.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-12-01?
entry.content:
Greetings, SAP Community! 

The SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Universal Model continues to advance, and in this blogpost, I will outline the latest features and enhancements designed to further improve efficiency, transparency, and agility in business modeling and performance analysis. 

Model 

Manage Transfer Structure new type Reverse Transfer Structure 

Transfer Structure is a Function that helps reshaping or enriching your data based on the rules you set up. Think of each rule as a simple ‚Äúif this happens, then do that‚Äù instruction. The ‚Äúif‚Äù part tells SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model when a rule should apply‚Äîbasically which rows to look at. The ‚Äúthen‚Äù part tells SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model what to change in those rows, like filling in certain fields or replacing values. If the data doesn‚Äôt meet the conditions in your rule, SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model just leaves it alone and passes it through untouched.‚ÄØ 

The Transfer Structure function now has two (2) Types.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ  

‚ÄØ 

With the new Reverse Transfer Structure type, it takes data that is spread across multiple columns and transforms it into rows. This is often called ‚Äúunpivoting‚Äù the data. It‚Äôs helpful when you need to turn wide tables into a long, tidy format that‚Äôs easier to analyze or use in calculations.‚ÄØ 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model  Transfer Structure > Reverse Transfer Structure‚ÄØ  

Data Screen Improvements: Global Renaming and Visibility Control  

Previously, a feature in the Data screen was introduced wherein you can rename the field description. When you changed a field name, it changed only in Data screen specific layout where the renaming of field was done. Now with the ‚ÄúStore Globally in Environment‚Äù option enabled, any field change which includes renaming, is automatically applied across all layouts within the same environment.‚ÄØ 

If a field in the Data Screen is renamed with the ‚ÄúStore Globally in Environment‚Äù option checked in the Edit Column dialog (opened by choosing Edit (pencil) icon), the new name is applied globally in all layouts of the environment. Renaming of such fields will also be applied globally, and the following message will be displayed: ‚ÄúField was renamed globally. Next renaming also will be applied globally.‚Äù. 

Apart from the field renaming enhancements in Data Screen, another enhancement has been done in Data screen wherein if the Field has the Control Type Hidden in the function configuration (Model Entity), the field will not be displayed in any Data screen layouts (Standard and Customized). It will no longer available in the Columns panel or Reports Show Elements and will also be excluded from exports. It will ensure consistent behavior and alignment with hidden field logic across all layouts. 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model Data Screen 

Process 

Transport Support for Manage Data Locks, Manage Data Privilege and Manage Layouts  

A new feature has been implemented in which Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts created for AddOn environment are now transportable wherein these will be included upon environment export when marked for transport, even if they refer to a function owned by a protected environment. Once exported, they can be moved to the target tenant through environment import. This also applies to regular/unprotected environments as well.  

Important points to note: 

  • During environment export, Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts will be excluded if it refers to a function or activity function (e.g. activity within runtime environment but assigned activity function from another runtime environment) from a different environment. There will be a warning message that will be prompted upon export action and logged in Event Logs. 
  • During environment import, Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts with inconsistent values (e.g. referring to a non-existing function or activity) will prompt an error message that a function or activity is missing in the target tenant.  
  • During AddOn environment import, the existence of the external function will be validated. If the function is not found in the target tenant, it will be removed from the corresponding Data Locks and Data Privileges. 

How does it work? 

For the following scenario, Tenant 01 will be the source tenant and Tenant 02 will be the target tenant. 

Source Tenant 01 - New field ‚ÄúTransport Data Privilege‚Äù checkbox is displayed in Data Privilege object page which can be marked as enabled and unmarked as disabled. This applies to Data Locks as well.  

Source Tenant 01 - Upon save of Data Privilege, it will show as ‚ÄúYes‚Äù when Transport Data Privilege checkbox is marked while it will show as ‚Äú-‚Äú when unmarked. This applies to Data Locks as well.  

When enabled, transportable Data Privileges and Data Locks will be included in the exported environment container.  

 

Target Tenant 02 - Upon environment import and activation, the transportable Data Privilege and Data Locks has been moved to the target tenant. 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model Manage Layouts, Manage Data Privileges, and Manage Data Locks 

Manage Process and Manage Activities: Updating Activity Run Status after Process reset  

 A new behavior has been implemented that the Run Status will be reset together with State of a dependent Activity. Run Status will change from its initial value after execution (which can be ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, ‚ÄúWarning‚Äù, or ‚ÄúError‚Äù) to its default value ‚ÄúNo Run‚Äù upon Process reset.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

The State of a dependent Activity will still have the same behavior wherein its initial value (which can be ‚ÄúActive‚Äù, ‚ÄúConfirmed‚Äù, or ‚ÄúRejected‚Äù) will be changed to its default value ‚ÄúInactive‚Äù once Process is reset. This behavior applies as well to Process and Activity elements in Report Screen.‚ÄØ 

The purpose of this change is to avoid misleading information when determining an Activity whether the task is completed or not.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

 Activity after Run is performed‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ 

 Process resetting‚ÄØ 

Activity after Process reset is performed‚ÄØ 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model  Manage Processes - Reset‚ÄØ 

Thank you for taking the time to read this update. 

We invite you to explore the newest enhancements in the SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model, and we encourage you to follow our ongoing ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù series. For previous updates, feel free to browse the PaPMCloudUMWhatsNew tag.

entry.title: Re: How to populated the VAT registration number for Busi...
entry.content:
Hi Emal,

In ECC, the tax numbers are stored in Tax number 1, 2,3,4,5 and VAT registration field which are separate fields on screen of XK01 and in table KNA1. However In S4 HANA, we have 1 tab for Tax Numbers which you have highlighted. In expects a category and tax number. Category is nothing but a combination of "Country cod and N".  N is derived based on where the tax is stored in ECC. If customer is from Italy and tax is stored in Tax number 1 in ECC then N = 1 and tax category in S4 HANA is IT1. Similarly Tax number 2 has value then IT2, Tax number 3 = IT3, Tax Number4 = IT4, Tax Number 5 = IT5 and VAT in ECC is 0 meaning tax category will always be IT0.

So in your case it would be category 0 for VAT number.

Customer Tax category     Tax Number

12345        DE0                     DE0000***

Please reward if you find this answer helpful. Also confirm if this helps

entry.title: Mastering GitOps with Argo CD: A Complete Guide to Declarative Kubernetes Deployments
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of cloud-native engineering, agility and reliability often clash. Developers need speed; operators need control. Traditional CI/CD pipelines, though effective, rely heavily on manual approvals, ad-hoc scripting, and push-based workflows ‚Äî all prone to configuration drift and human error.

GitOps changes the game by using Git as the single source of truth for both infrastructure and application configurations. With Argo CD, a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery controller, you can automate deployments, enforce configuration consistency, and self-heal your clusters ‚Äî all through declarative manifests stored in Git.

This article provides an end-to-end, production-ready walkthrough of how to design, deploy, and operate Kubernetes workloads using Argo CD and GitOps principles ‚Äî including advanced features such as multi-environment automation, Helm integration, sync policies, and best practices for scale.

What Is GitOps?

GitOps is a modern methodology for managing and operating cloud-native infrastructure and applications using Git as the single source of truth. It shifts the deployment paradigm from manual, imperative commands (like kubectl apply) to a declarative, automated workflow, where the desired state of your system is stored and versioned in Git.

Key principles of GitOps include:

1. Git as the Source of Truth

  • All infrastructure and application configurations are defined declaratively in Git.
  • Git commits represent the desired system state, enabling versioning, traceability, and auditability.

2. Pull-Based Automation

  • A GitOps operator continuously monitors Git for changes and reconciles the live system with the desired state.
  • Any drift between Git and the running environment is detected and corrected automatically.

3. Automated Rollbacks and Auditing

  • Since every change is a Git commit, rolling back to a previous state is as simple as reverting a commit.
  • All actions are auditable, providing a clear history of changes and deployments.

In essence: With GitOps, you declare what you want, commit it to Git, and let automation ensure that your cluster matches that desired state ‚Äî reliably, securely, and consistently.

It combines the benefits of version control, CI/CD, and automation into a single, streamlined approach for managing modern cloud-native applications.

Why Choose Argo CD?

Argo CD is a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery tool that fully implements GitOps principles, making it an ideal choice for teams seeking automation, reliability, and scalability. Here‚Äôs why Argo CD stands out:

1. Continuous Synchronization

  • Automatically monitors Git repositories and synchronizes changes to Kubernetes clusters.
  • Ensures the live state always matches the desired state defined in Git.

2. Real-Time Drift Detection and Self-Healing

  • Detects any manual changes or configuration drift in the cluster.
  • Automatically corrects deviations to maintain consistency.

3. Multi-Cluster and Multi-Environment Support

  • Manage deployments across multiple clusters and environments from a single Argo CD instance.
  • Supports environment overlays for dev, staging, and production setups.

4. Application Visualization and Health Monitoring

  • Provides a UI and CLI to visualize application status, dependencies, and health.
  • Supports monitoring health states like Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, or Suspended.

5. Support for Multiple Deployment Tools

  • Deploy raw YAML, Helm charts, Kustomize overlays, or Jsonnet configurations.
  • Flexible enough to handle simple apps or complex, multi-service systems.

6. Secure and Role-Based Access

  • Built-in RBAC for controlling access to applications, clusters, and repositories.
  • Ensures secure operations in collaborative, multi-team environments.

In short: Argo CD transforms Git commits into the live state of your Kubernetes clusters ‚Äî consistently, automatically, and safely ‚Äî making it a trusted GitOps engine for modern cloud-native deployments.

Step 1: Setting Up Argo CD

Let‚Äôs deploy Argo CD in a Kubernetes cluster.

Prerequisites

  • A Kubernetes cluster (Minikube, Kind, AKS, EKS, or GKE)
  • kubectl installed and configured
  • A GitHub or GitLab repository for your manifests

Installing Commands

kubectl create namespace argocd
kubectl apply -n argocd \
  -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/argoproj/argo-cd/stable/manifests/install.yaml

Once deployed, Argo CD runs several components:

  • argocd-server ‚Äì exposes the UI, API, and CLI
  • argocd-repo-server ‚Äì interacts with Git repositories
  • argocd-application-controller ‚Äì reconciles application states
  • argocd-dex-server ‚Äì handles authentication
  • argocd-redis ‚Äì caching and internal coordination

Accessing the UI

kubectl port-forward svc/argocd-server -n argocd 8080:443

Then open https://localhost:8080.

Retrieve the admin password:

kubectl -n argocd get secret argocd-initial-admin-secret \
  -o jsonpath="{.data.password}" | base64 -d

 

Step 2: Connecting a Git Repository

In the Argo CD UI:
Settings ‚Üí Repositories ‚Üí Connect Repo ‚Üí Add Git URL + Credentials.

Alternatively, via CLI:

argocd repo add https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git \
  --username <user> --password <token>

Argo CD now watches this repository and continuously scans it for configuration changes.

Step 3: Creating and Deploying Applications

Applications are the core Argo CD resources. They define what to deploy, where, and how.

Sample Application Definition

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: nginx-demo
  namespace: argocd
spec:
  project: default
  source:
    repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git
    path: apps/nginx
    targetRevision: main
  destination:
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
    namespace: demo
  syncPolicy:
    automated:
      prune: true
      selfHeal: true
    syncOptions:
      - CreateNamespace=true

Apply this:

kubectl apply -f nginx-application.yaml

Argo CD fetches the manifests, applies them to the cluster, and keeps them in sync with Git automatically.

 

Step 4: Understanding Deployment Strategies

Argo CD supports multiple deployment approaches:

1. Plain YAML

Store raw manifests under version control ‚Äî simplest setup but less flexible.

2. Helm Charts

Argo CD can deploy Helm charts directly without helm CLI:

source:
  repoURL: https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami
  chart: nginx
  targetRevision: 13.2.9
  helm:
    values: |
      replicaCount: 3
      service:
        type: ClusterIP

3. Kustomize Overlays

Perfect for multi-environment management:

my-app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ base/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ deployment.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ service.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ overlays/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dev/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ prod/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml

4. App-of-Apps Pattern

Used to manage complex systems:

source:
  repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/environment-configs.git
  path: environments/dev

Step 5: Configuration and Synchronization

Sync Policies

Argo CD supports both manual and automated synchronization.

  • Manual Mode: Operators review and trigger syncs manually.
  • Automated Mode: Argo CD applies changes as soon as they are committed to Git.

Example:

syncPolicy:
  automated:
    prune: true
    selfHeal: true
  • Prune removes obsolete resources that no longer exist in Git.
  • SelfHeal ensures that any manual cluster change is automatically reverted.

Sync Options

Argo CD provides advanced sync behaviors:

syncOptions:
  - CreateNamespace=true
  - ApplyOutOfSyncOnly=true
  - PrunePropagationPolicy=foreground

Hooks and Lifecycle Management

You can use Argo CD Resource Hooks to run pre- and post-deployment tasks like database migrations or config validation.

Example:

metadata:
  annotations:
    argocd.argoproj.io/hook: PreSync

Step 6: Observability and Health Monitoring

Argo CD continuously monitors application health using Kubernetes object statuses.

  • Health states: Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, Suspended
  • You can visualize these in the Argo CD UI tree view.

For deeper insights:

  • Metrics: Argo CD exposes Prometheus metrics at /metrics.
  • Dashboards: Integrate with Grafana to visualize sync frequency, drift count, and app health.
  • Notifications: Use Argo CD Notifications for Slack, Teams, or email alerts.

Example config:

triggers:
  - name: on-sync-failure
    condition: app.status.sync.status == 'OutOfSync'
    template: sync-failure

Step 7: Real-World Deployment Workflow

Here‚Äôs a simplified GitOps deployment lifecycle using Argo CD:

  1. Developer updates the manifest or Helm values ‚Üí commits to Git.
  2. CI validates YAML syntax and performs static checks.
  3. Commit is merged to the main branch.
  4. Argo CD detects the commit, fetches the new configuration, and starts reconciliation.
  5. Application is deployed to the cluster.
  6. If any manual drift occurs, Argo CD flags ‚ÄúOutOfSync‚Äù and reverts automatically.
  7. Rollback is as easy as git revert <commit-hash>.

This process guarantees full traceability, automatic rollback, and no manual cluster changes.

Summary: Argo CD as the GitOps Engine

Argo CD brings automation, reliability, and control to Kubernetes deployments through GitOps. It replaces manual, error-prone processes with a declarative, Git-driven model where every change is versioned, traceable, and automatically synchronized to clusters. As environments scale across microservices and multiple clusters, Argo CD ensures consistency, eliminates drift, and enables faster, safer releases. Ultimately, it transforms Git into the operational control plane and provides a predictable, self-healing, and highly observable deployment workflow ‚Äî allowing teams to move quickly without compromising stability.

You define your desired state once, commit to Git, and Argo CD ensures your clusters reflect it ‚Äî continuously and automatically.

This declarative model brings:

  • Auditability: every change is a commit
  • Reliability: drift is self-corrected
  • Scalability: consistent rollout across clusters
  • Security: code-based governance over live clusters

Conclusion

Argo CD is more than a deployment tool ‚Äî it is the operational engine that modernizes how organizations manage Kubernetes at scale. By embracing GitOps, teams shift from fragile, manual, push-based deployments to a fully automated, audit-ready, and self-healing delivery model. Every environment becomes predictable, every rollout becomes traceable, and every configuration becomes reproducible.

As applications grow into distributed microservices and clusters expand across regions or clouds, Argo CD provides the consistency and governance required to keep everything in sync. Its declarative, pull-based architecture eliminates configuration drift, while features like automated sync, app-of-apps orchestration, Helm/Kustomize support, and environment overlays allow teams to design enterprise-grade delivery pipelines with confidence.

In essence, Argo CD turns Git into a control plane for your entire Kubernetes footprint. It bridges the gap between developers and operators by delivering a unified, reliable, and observable deployment workflow.

Adopting GitOps with Argo CD is not just a tooling decision ‚Äî it is an engineering culture upgrade. It empowers teams to deploy faster, recover instantly, collaborate better, and operate with clarity at every stage of the software lifecycle.

In a world where speed and stability are equally critical, Argo CD ensures you never have to choose between the two.

entry.title: Re: The destination set for ur participant ID does not ma...
entry.content:
Root cause:

  • The participant ID you are using as the sender in eCockpit is linked to a destination that does not correspond to the system from which you are submitting the document.
  • This often happens when:
    • The destination in SAP BTP is incorrectly configured.
    • The participant ID mapping in the Master Data Management app or Peppol Exchange Service is missing or incorrect.
    • The wrong system alias or destination name is assigned in the eDocument Cockpit configuration

Solution

The destination set for your participant ID does not match the system you are trying to submit the electronic document from‚Äù in SAP eDocument Cockpit (eCockpit) usually occurs due to a mismatch between the participant ID configuration and the destination system settings in SAP BTP.

1. Verify Participant ID Setup

  • Go to SAP Document and Reporting Compliance ‚Üí Master Data Management App.
  • Check that the participant ID is registered and linked to the correct system.
  • If using Peppol or similar network, ensure the participant ID is active for sending (and optionally receiving) documents

2. Check Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

  • Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  • Navigate to Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations.
  • Confirm:
    • The destination name matches what is configured in eCockpit.
    • The URL/host points to the correct system (S/4HANA or middleware).
    • Authentication settings are correct.
  • If needed, edit and save the destination

3. Validate Additional Parameters

  • In the destination configuration, check Additional Properties:
    • sap-client (client number)
    • systemAlias or similar identifiers
  • These must match the system you are submitting from.

4. Update eCockpit Settings

  • In EDOC_COCKPIT or Manage Electronic Documents (Fiori):
    • Ensure the communication arrangement (e.g., SAP_COM_0521) is linked to the correct destination.
    • If using Integration Suite, verify the outbound service destination is correct.

5. Clear and Retry

  • After correcting configuration:
    • Clear the error in eCockpit.
    • Resubmit the document

entry.title: Re: how to upgrade SAP BTP trial account to free tier acc...
entry.content:
Hi jerlin_d,

as far as I know an upgrade from your personal trial account to an enterprise free tier account is not possible.

Please open https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core and log in with your SAP user (version: For SAP developer should be displayed) to get info how you as SAP user get provisioned SAP AI Core into an account.

Hope that helps. Best regards, Jens

entry.title: Re: how to upgrade SAP BTP trial account to free tier acc...
entry.content:
Hi jerlin_d,

Furthermore, I want to emphasize that 'Free Tier' is not an account type, but a "set of free services that can be used within an enterprise account", for details see below reference [1].
There you could also find how to get an enterprise account, where 'Free Tier', set set of free services, can be use.

Your personal free trial is not an enterprise account, and even though you can use there many BTP Services for free, not all of the 'Free Tier' is currently offered in personal trial accounts, like SAP AI Core.

Hope that helps.
Best regards, Jens

[1] https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/getting-global-account?version=Cloud
